Abstract: This study delves into the ecological roles and adaptive mechanisms of fungi inhabiting extreme environments, specifically glacial ice and hypersaline waters. Fungi, known for their remarkable adaptability, exhibit unique physiological and biochemical traits that enable survival in such harsh conditions. The research focuses on halophilic and psychrophilic fungi, which thrive in high salinity and low temperatures, respectively. By analyzing samples from these environments, we aim to uncover the genetic and metabolic pathways that facilitate their extremophilic lifestyle. The findings contribute to our understanding of fungal biodiversity and resilience, offering insights into potential biotechnological applications, including bioremediation and the production of novel enzymes. This investigation not only expands our knowledge of life in extreme habitats but also underscores the importance of fungi in global biogeochemical cycles.
